trans-unit.source: Configure SSL for a cloud service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure SSL for a cloud service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to specify an HTTPS endpoint for a web role and how to upload an SSL certificate to secure your application.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to specify an HTTPS endpoint for a web role and how to upload an SSL certificate to secure your application.

trans-unit.source: Secure Socket Layer (SSL) encryption is the most commonly used method of securing data sent across the internet.
trans-unit.target: Secure Socket Layer (SSL) encryption is the most commonly used method of securing data sent across the internet.

trans-unit.source: This common task discusses how to specify an HTTPS endpoint for a web role and how to upload an SSL certificate to secure your application.
trans-unit.target: This common task discusses how to specify an HTTPS endpoint for a web role and how to upload an SSL certificate to secure your application.

trans-unit.source: The procedures in this task apply to Azure Cloud Services; for Websites, see <linkText>Configuring an SSL certificate for an Azure website</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The procedures in this task apply to Azure Cloud Services; for Websites, see <linkText>Configuring an SSL certificate for an Azure website</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This task will use a production deployment; information on using a staging deployment is provided at the end of this topic.
trans-unit.target: This task will use a production deployment; information on using a staging deployment is provided at the end of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Read <linkText>this</linkText><title></title> first if you have not yet created a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Read <linkText>this</linkText><title></title> first if you have not yet created a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: To configure SSL for an application, you first need to get an SSL certificate that has been signed by a Certificate Authority (CA), a trusted third-party who issues certificates for this purpose.
trans-unit.target: To configure SSL for an application, you first need to get an SSL certificate that has been signed by a Certificate Authority (CA), a trusted third-party who issues certificates for this purpose.

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have one, you will need to obtain one from a company that sells SSL certificates.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have one, you will need to obtain one from a company that sells SSL certificates.

trans-unit.source: The certificate must meet the following requirements for SSL certificates in Azure:
trans-unit.target: The certificate must meet the following requirements for SSL certificates in Azure:

trans-unit.source: The certificate must contain a private key.
trans-unit.target: The certificate must contain a private key.

trans-unit.source: The certificate must be created for key exchange, exportable to a Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.
trans-unit.target: The certificate must be created for key exchange, exportable to a Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) file.

trans-unit.source: The certificate's subject name must match the domain used to access the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The certificate's subject name must match the domain used to access the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You cannot obtain an SSL certificate from a certificate authority (CA) for the cloudapp.net domain.
trans-unit.target: You cannot obtain an SSL certificate from a certificate authority (CA) for the cloudapp.net domain.

trans-unit.source: You must acquire a custom domain name to use when access your service.
trans-unit.target: You must acquire a custom domain name to use when access your service.

trans-unit.source: When you request a certificate from a CA the certificate's subject name must match the custom domain name used to access your application.
trans-unit.target: When you request a certificate from a CA the certificate's subject name must match the custom domain name used to access your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your custom domain name is contoso.com you would request a certificate from your CA for *.contoso.com or www.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your custom domain name is contoso.com you would request a certificate from your CA for *.contoso.com or www.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: The certificate must use a minimum of 2048-bit encryption.
trans-unit.target: The certificate must use a minimum of 2048-bit encryption.

trans-unit.source: For test purposes, you can <linkText>create</linkText><title></title> and use a self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: For test purposes, you can <linkText>create</linkText><title></title> and use a self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: A self-signed certificate is not authenticated through a CA and can use the cloudapp.net domain as the website URL.
trans-unit.target: A self-signed certificate is not authenticated through a CA and can use the cloudapp.net domain as the website URL.

trans-unit.source: For example, the task below uses a self-signed certificate in which the common name (CN) used in the certificate is sslexample.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, the task below uses a self-signed certificate in which the common name (CN) used in the certificate is sslexample.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: Next, you must include information about the certificate in your service definition and service configuration files.
trans-unit.target: Next, you must include information about the certificate in your service definition and service configuration files.

trans-unit.source: Your application must be configured to use the certificate, and an HTTPS endpoint must be added.
trans-unit.target: Your application must be configured to use the certificate, and an HTTPS endpoint must be added.

trans-unit.source: As a result, the service definition and service configuration files need to be updated.
trans-unit.target: As a result, the service definition and service configuration files need to be updated.

trans-unit.source: In your development environment, open the service definition file (CSDEF), add a Certificates section within the WebRole section, and include the following information about the certificate:
trans-unit.target: In your development environment, open the service definition file (CSDEF), add a Certificates section within the WebRole section, and include the following information about the certificate:

trans-unit.source: The Certificates section defines the name of our certificate, its location, and the name of the store where it is located.
trans-unit.target: The Certificates section defines the name of our certificate, its location, and the name of the store where it is located.

trans-unit.source: We have chosen to store the certificate in the CA (Certificate Authority)tore, but you can choose other options as well.
trans-unit.target: We have chosen to store the certificate in the CA (Certificate Authority)tore, but you can choose other options as well.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>How to associate a certificate with a service</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>How to associate a certificate with a service</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: In your service definition file, add an InputEndpoint element within the Endpoints section to enable HTTPS:
trans-unit.target: In your service definition file, add an InputEndpoint element within the Endpoints section to enable HTTPS:

trans-unit.source: In your service definition file, add a Binding element within the Sites section.
trans-unit.target: In your service definition file, add a Binding element within the Sites section.

trans-unit.source: This adds an HTTPS binding to map the endpoint to your site:
trans-unit.target: This adds an HTTPS binding to map the endpoint to your site:

trans-unit.source: All of the required changes to the service definition file have been completed, but you still need to add the certificate information to the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: All of the required changes to the service definition file have been completed, but you still need to add the certificate information to the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: In your service configuration file (CSCFG), ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg, add a Certificates section within the Role section, replacing the sample thumbprint value shown below with that of your certificate:
trans-unit.target: In your service configuration file (CSCFG), ServiceConfiguration.Cloud.cscfg, add a Certificates section within the Role section, replacing the sample thumbprint value shown below with that of your certificate:

trans-unit.source: (The example above uses sha1 for the thumbprint algorithm.
trans-unit.target: (The example above uses sha1 for the thumbprint algorithm.

trans-unit.source: Specify the appropriate value for your certificate's thumbprint algorithm.)
trans-unit.target: Specify the appropriate value for your certificate's thumbprint algorithm.)

trans-unit.source: Now that the service definition and service configuration files have been updated, package your deployment for uploading to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that the service definition and service configuration files have been updated, package your deployment for uploading to Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you are using cspack, ensure that you don't use the /generateConfigurationFile flag, as that will overwrite the certificate information you just inserted.
trans-unit.target: If you are using cspack, ensure that you don't use the /generateConfigurationFile flag, as that will overwrite the certificate information you just inserted.

trans-unit.source: Your deployment package has been updated to use the certificate, and an HTTPS endpoint has been added.
trans-unit.target: Your deployment package has been updated to use the certificate, and an HTTPS endpoint has been added.

trans-unit.source: Now you can upload the package and certificate to Azure with the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Now you can upload the package and certificate to Azure with the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click on Cloud Services on the left-side navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: Click on Cloud Services on the left-side navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: Click on the desired cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Click on the desired cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Certificates tab.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Certificates tab.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click the Certificates tab</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click the Certificates tab</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Upload button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Upload button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Upload</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upload</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Provide the File, Password, then click Complete (the checkmark).
trans-unit.target: Provide the File, Password, then click Complete (the checkmark).

trans-unit.source: Now that your deployment is up and running in Azure, you can connect to it using HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Now that your deployment is up and running in Azure, you can connect to it using HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, select your deployment, then click the link under Site URL.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, select your deployment, then click the link under Site URL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Determine site URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Determine site URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In your web browser, modify the link to use https instead of http, and then visit the page.
trans-unit.target: In your web browser, modify the link to use https instead of http, and then visit the page.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you are using a self-signed certificate, when you browse to an HTTPS endpoint that's associated with the self-signed certificate you will see a certificate error in the browser.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you are using a self-signed certificate, when you browse to an HTTPS endpoint that's associated with the self-signed certificate you will see a certificate error in the browser.

trans-unit.source: Using a certificate signed by a trusted certification authority will eliminate this problem; in the meantime, you can ignore the error.
trans-unit.target: Using a certificate signed by a trusted certification authority will eliminate this problem; in the meantime, you can ignore the error.

trans-unit.source: (Another option is to add the self-signed certificate to the user's trusted certificate authority certificate store.)
trans-unit.target: (Another option is to add the self-signed certificate to the user's trusted certificate authority certificate store.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SSL example web site</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SSL example web site</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you want to use SSL for a staging deployment instead of a production deployment, you'll first need to determine the URL used for the staging deployment.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use SSL for a staging deployment instead of a production deployment, you'll first need to determine the URL used for the staging deployment.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your cloud service to the staging environment without including a certificate or any certificate information.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your cloud service to the staging environment without including a certificate or any certificate information.

trans-unit.source: Once deployed, you can determine the GUID-based URL, which is listed in the management portal's Site URL field.
trans-unit.target: Once deployed, you can determine the GUID-based URL, which is listed in the management portal's Site URL field.

trans-unit.source: Create a certificate with the common name (CN) equal to the GUID-based URL (for example, 32818777-6e77-4ced-a8fc-57609d404462.cloudapp.net), use the management portal to add the certificate to your staged cloud service, add the certificate information to your CSDEF and CSCFG files, repackage your application, and update your staged deployment to use the new package and CSCFG file.
trans-unit.target: Create a certificate with the common name (CN) equal to the GUID-based URL (for example, 32818777-6e77-4ced-a8fc-57609d404462.cloudapp.net), use the management portal to add the certificate to your staged cloud service, add the certificate information to your CSDEF and CSCFG files, repackage your application, and update your staged deployment to use the new package and CSCFG file.

trans-unit.source: http://manage.windowsazure.com
trans-unit.target: http://manage.windowsazure.com
